leads.lead_text: Basal lamina directly above alar region entirely occupied by thin-walled hyaline cells
Basal lamina directly above alar region partly occupied by firm- to thick-walled and often pitted chlorophyllose cells, often with a hyaline border
Apices of some or all vegetative leaves cucullate
Apices of vegetative leaves not cucullate
Leaves ± flexuose when dry, with apices curved in all directions
Leaves straight or homomallously curved when dry
Chlorophyllose cells in transition from hyaline to chlorophyllose laminal cells elongate to oblong, pitted
Chlorophyllose cells in transition from hyaline to chlorophyllose laminal cells isodiametric to short-oblong, not pitted
Hairpoint when present straight, never reflexed; abaxial costa smooth or weakly ribbed near apex; adaxial costa with stereids, at least towards apex
Hairpoint when present often reflexed, sometimes straight; abaxial costa toothed near apex; adaxial costa with hyalocysts or cells with a large lumen throughout
Hairpoint often short and straight, never reflexed, rarely absent; laminal cells in apical half rhomboidal to rectangular or quadrate
Hairpoint often long and reflexed, rarely straight or short or absent; laminal cells in apical half rhomboidal to elliptic
Leaf apices obtuse, cucullate (comal leaves can have a hyaline point); costa occupying c. 12–20% of leaf width at base, with conspicuous side nerves
Leaf apices acuminate; costa occupying c. 30–50% of leaf width at base, without conspicuous side nerves
